name: Lagrangian submanifold
rephrased: A Lagrangian submanifold is a special type of submanifold in a symplectic manifold where the symplectic form vanishes completely when restricted to it, and its dimension is half that of the ambient manifold.
implication_form: If M is a symplectic manifold with symplectic form ω, and L is a submanifold of M with dimension half of dim(M), then L is Lagrangian if ω, restricted to L, is identically zero.
posed_by: Named after Joseph-Louis Lagrange, though formally defined in modern symplectic geometry.
explained: A Lagrangian submanifold is a special type of submanifold defined within a symplectic manifold. It is a smooth submanifold L of a symplectic manifold (M, ω) such that the symplectic form ω restricts to zero on L, i.e., ω|_L = 0. Crucially, it must have the same dimension as the space of symplectic forms allow, which is half the dimension of the ambient symplectic manifold M (if M is even-dimensional). Furthermore, for the submanifold to be Lagrangian, it must be maximal isotropic, meaning its dimension is maximal among isotropic submanifolds (those where ω restricts to zero). In the context of Hamiltonian mechanics, Lagrangian submanifolds arise naturally as the submanifolds where the action functional is defined, representing the possible trajectories of a system starting from an initial position and momenta.
